Armada is unable to resolve tiller-deploy.kube-system.svc.cluster.local because it is running as a container on the host and only has access to the local resolv.conf for DNS servers.  dnsmasq is not running prior to the unlock, so trying to install an application before the unlock will fail because it can't resolve the host that is only known to K8s coredns.

If/when Armada runs as a Pod, it would then be able to resolve this address since it will be running in the K8s cluster.  Therefore the k8s DNS service would not need to be temporarily added to the host resolv.conf.

Firstly, if get_placement_needed_info_and_report() failed, it will effect for adding the next resource (devices). So we add "try ... except" to break the internal *for* cycle, and continue resource adding even if some resources report error.

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
This should be down in the bowels of refresh_connection_info:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f5d0d85285c894b48c463e3b72646537db90514d/nova/virt/block_device.py#L641

Then you can simply pass the refresh flag to _get_instance_block_device_info and that will do the thing for the new-style attachments (bdms that have attachment_id set). And it would do the proper refresh for old-style attachments (initialize connection calls to the storage backend to get a new connection_info dict).

Also, what I'm proposing will save the updated bdm.connection_info into the database, something you're not doing here.

Note that currently today refresh_connection_info doesn't update the attachment record, it just gets the attachment record and pulls the connection_info off it, which is stored in the cinder database. So it's not really doing a refresh.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/f5d0d85285c894b48c463e3b72646537db90514d/nova/virt/block_device.py#L653

nova/virt/block_device.py.message: So we're getting a lot of test failures, but nothing really obviously failing in the cinder API. However, I want to say I don't think this is how this API is meant to be used, but would need jgriffith properly to help us. My understanding is rather than update an existing attachment with a new connector (which is how we would have done things in the past when we just had a single volume and no cardinality on the attachments themselves), we should be creating a new attachment with the new host connector and then deleting the old attachment. That would also result in a new attachment_id which we'd need to storage on self so it gets updated in the backing BlockDeviceMapping (see the @update_db decorator).

Per http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122170.html we said we wouldn't fail the entire operation if this fails:

"We also said we wouldn't fail the operation if the refresh fails for whatever reason, like if Cinder fails."

In that case I think it just means if we get a Cinder error of some kind we log it and return so we're left with the BDM.connection_info we already have and hope it's correct.

You're 100% correct Matt, the design was in fact to instead make connections sort of "ephemeral" and just create a new one.  Update is there as a special case to handle a way of creating an attachment before you're scheduled to a compute node (so you can pass the connector to it when you actually have the Server scheduled).

The naming is somewhat unfortunate, "finalize" is probably a better name for this method as that's the primary intent.

No this is wrong, we shouldn't be using these old methods for dealing with attachments when we have an attachment_id. The bdm.attachment_id means we're doing the new style attachment stuff, so we create/update/delete attachments rather than init/terminate connections.

As noted earlier:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/579004/2/nova/virt/block_device.py@653

So I think what you want is something like this:

# Keep track of the existing attachment_id so we can delete it.
old_attachment_id = self['attachment_id']
# Create a new attachment with the current host connector.
# This will give us an attachment with fresh connection_info.
attachment_ref = volume_api.attachment_create(
    context, self.volume_id, instance.uuid,
    connector=connector)
# Save the attachment_id on this bdm (see @update_db).
self['attachment_id'] = attachment_ref['id']
# Now that we've got a new attachment, delete the old one.
volume_api.attachment_delete(context, old_attachment_id)

And I think you might need to also complete the attachment to make sure the volume status is in-use at the end:

  volume_api.attachment_complete(context, attachment_ref['id'])

If you're testing this in devstack, you'll know attachment_complete is needed if you omit it and the volume status is 'reserved' when you're done with the operation (reboot would be a good test).

Yes!  +1 to the notes from Matt.  The whole goal was to avoid re-initializing attachments and instead just create a new one and delete the old one.  This change is perfect for putting the old style attachment code back in, but that would make me very sad.

Here, error on tempest, because self['attachment_id'] supposed to be changed after rebooting but it didn't. 
In this function, attachment_id is passed as a parameter, but why self['attachment_id'] is used?
We don't actually need this given the @update_db decorator. I also don't understand the reason for the conditional here.

You should be correct but I tested a lot of code and I finally figured out It has old attachment_id in this method. It caused detaching volume fail. Please take a look at this and advice me what to do or something. Thanks.

Got it, thanks for the update Lee. Will keep an eye on the ML.

Timing, I've been approaching this from a different angle for a NFS snapshot issue in Ibbd17dce9763511361cc4236661f834864e13d53 and ran up agains this.

I don't think we can do this without a new cinder API tbh, even the v3 attachment_update API eventually calls down into the intilaize_connection code path on the c-vol side 
 [1][2] hitting the same issues as the pure v2 initialize_connection calls that were raised before.

I'm going to poke the thread to see if any folks want to work on this in V now U is over.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/99c09bddceca754b550955db7e6786686316d525/cinder/volume/manager.py#L4551-L4554
[2] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/99c09bddceca754b550955db7e6786686316d525/cinder/volume/manager.py#L4496-L4504

I've had no replies overnight on the ML so I'll dump my idea here and on the thread shortly.

- Have the c-vol drivers return a flag in their connection_info to indicate when calls to intialize_connection/attachment_update are idempotent. This will allow n-cpu to know here when it's safe to call intialize_connection/attachment_update to fully refresh the connection_info. Both changes should be backportable.

- For the specific ceph MON update issue here, introduce a backportable workaround configurable that forces a refresh of the connection_info for running instances somehow, either through a periodic job, start up of n-cpu or some other trigger.

- Introduce a new c-api v3 API to refresh an attachments connection_info, essentially do all of the above on the Cinder side and have n-cpu call that instead of checking connection_info for the idempotent flag. This wouldn't be backportable.

- Introduce a new n-api API to trigger the refresh of a specific attachments connection_info via the above c-api API. This wouldn't be backportable.

- Not related to this issue but we could then also introduce a new c-api v3 API to migrate from v2 exports to v3 attachments using the above refresh logic, again on the Cinder side.

- Finally remove the idempotent connection_info flag and workaround option.

Thoughts?
Any thoughts on fixing this for the new API and leaving the old API path unpatched? Would that be a viable step forward? It seems as if that could at least fix new deployments going forward.

tasks/collect/container.yml.message:
Please avoid use of hardcoded /tmp path, ask the system to return it.

In fact is better to rely on ansible ability to create an run a script file instead of doing it twice. 

Have you tried to use https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/script_module.html ?

You can include the timeout inside the script itself and pass the custom value as an argument, or via an environment variale. Either way, you will endup with a single-task in ansible, and a shell script that can easily be tested.

I saw a lot of issues for async in case of finishing command by timeout, also it doesn't work with script https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/20232

Anyway, shell timeout is good enough to do it, it doesn't have disadvantages and very reliable. Alternative solution can't be a reason for "-1", please read openstack review guidelines.

"/tmp" is safest place to place a temporary script that we run once and forget.

Using timeout for every command is much worse and brings a huge overhead, better to use it only once and for whole script as it's done here.

Async with timeout doesn't work stable and has issues, but anyway it's one more task, so better to use shell timeout that always works.

Why it's impossible to use script please read again our discussion and ansible docs: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/script_module.html

I think I explained this well enough.

tasks/collect/container.yml.message:
I did read all previous comments twice but I still failed to see any explanations for why you decided to go for adding an extra task and creating a nested shell call for this feature.

The are two documented ways of implementing a timeout with ansible: the async approach and the shell timeout one.

You already have a script, so if you want to add timeout to it, add it inside "collect-container-logs.sh" file and avoid making the playbook more complex.

The currently propose approach also has performance downsides as it is increases the number of tasks executed (while this is avoidable).

As I stated in previous comment, I trust more that Ansible ability to transfer and execute a script in a portable way, than the current implementation that uses hardcoded /tmp.

author.status: do not feed the troll 🥕

tasks/collect/container.yml.message:
I would like to see proofs that ansible async "doesn't work stable and has issues" statement.

I am not aware of any critical bugs open with Ansible about and the team is advertising it as recommended way to run tasks in background or to implement timeouts. Can you please provide any backing links?

The first question about not using hardcoded /tmp was ignored. The same happened about suggestion to include timeout implementation inside collect-container-logs.sh script, so we do not have to touch the script call.
I'm aware of script module, please read the all comments for a previous patches before review.
does it have to be /tmp?  if you place it in the workspace we'll at least log the script itself in case there is an issue

We do have logs of the script as we did before, *nothing changed* here:
from this patch: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/c5aa545e29c44304a82946894a29571c/log/logs/quickstart_collect_logs.log#4292

from regular patch: https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/714e4beec31e4c52bc5a98d094863028/log/logs/quickstart_collect_logs.log#4291

Rather than do this, I'd suggest putting timeouts into the script where you can be more surgical about what is essential and what is not. Either that, or pull the script contents out into async ansible tasks. Something like this was suggested in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/717604/6/tasks/collect/container.yml already.

I'd normally suggest making the script run as an async ansible task to implement a timeout, but according to https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/20232 that will not work because the script module does not require python on the target host and therefore cannot be implemented as an async task.

@Jesse, sorry, but it's completely overhead to add "timeout" for each command and it doesn't provide any additional value to do it. Async doesn't work with shell and it had issues with finishing task by timeout for all other modules, I can't find the concrete issue now, but saw this a lot. In this case I'd prefer to use stable "timeout" of shell once for a whole script.

I don't think we want kubernetes specifics in this file. I know it is more work, but I think a better way might be to:
- Add a new update_host_config_upgrade method to the BasePuppet class (that does nothing).
- Implement that method only in the KubernetesPuppet plugin.
- The update_host_config_upgrade would then call the new method on all the plugins (as per update_host_config). However, the host_config file can't be replaced then (by calling _write_host_config). Instead, a new _merge_host_config method would be required to load the host config from the existing yaml file and merge any entries coming back from update_host_config_upgrade.

I did a test in neutron and supplying both ipv4 and ipv6 options seem to work.
I put a details in http://paste.openstack.org/show/791438/ including packet capture output.

I used iPXE as a client and ran:
 IPv4 test: ifconf --configurator dhcp net0
 IPv6 test: ifconf --configurator ipv6 net0

This might be problematic. Let's say you have a network with existing nodes that only support IPv4, i.e the hardware can only network boot on IPv4. You want to migrate to IPv6 so dual stack is enabled. If neutron put's the IPv6 address in position [0] of the fixed_ips array, we will use IPv6 options, the older systems that only support IPv4 can no longer be deployed, cleaned etc.

Maybe a "safer" approach would be to use IPv4 options if any fixed_ip with version 4 is present? (This would make it impossible to configure new systems to only use IPv6.)

Do we have a bug regarding providing options for both ip_version in neutron?

Well, according to the docs [1], a SYS021 indicates "The command failed to set %s".  The docs don't specify what failures can cause this to happen though.  We know that this error is thrown in the following cases:
- node is off and we send a power off
- node is on and we send a power on
- node is off and we send a reboot

It may occur in other cases though, such as a general failure, and we may not want to power on in those cases.

openstack-helm-infra/files/0009-Enable-o.message:
It's better to move it to below existed section.
pod:
  probes:
    server:
      mariadb:
        readiness:
          enabled: true
          params:
            initialDelaySeconds: 30
            periodSeconds: 30
            timeoutSeconds: 15

The problem that Joseph mentioned is due to the symbol "-" here as it chomps whitespaces(newlines are whitespaces).

In the case that "enabled is false" for startup, it removes the contents inside of {{ and }}, but it leaves the remaining whitespace as is.

"-}}" removes the newline and the whitespaces before "volumeMounts" which causes the indent issue that looks like this,
          readinessProbe:
            exec:
              command:
              - /tmp/readiness.sh
            failureThreshold: 3
            initialDelaySeconds: 30
            periodSeconds: 30
            timeoutSeconds: 15
                    volumeMounts:
            - name: pod-tmp

To trim the whitespaces, do this instead.
{{ dict "envAll" . "component" "server" "container" "mariadb" "type" "readiness" "probeTemplate" (include "mariadbReadinessProbe" . | fromYaml) | include "helm-toolkit.snippets.kubernetes_probe" | trim | indent 10 }}
{{ dict "envAll" . "component" "server" "container" "mariadb" "type" "startup" "probeTemplate" (include "mariadbReadinessProbe" . | fromYaml) | include "helm-toolkit.snippets.kubernetes_probe" | trim | indent 10 }}

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
FYI: in my testing it didn't function at all when I ran:

  openstack server create --flavor tiny --image $IMG_ID --key-name dcn0-key --network dcn0-network --security-group basic --availability-zone dcn0 --boot-from-volume 4 pet-server-dcn0

The above will only work if the Nova `cross_az_attach` setting of the relevant compute node is set to `false`. With this change it will be automatically configured by deploying with `environments/dcn-hci.yaml`. If the `cross_az_attach` setting is `true` (the default), then the volume will be created from the image not in the dcn site, but on the default central site (as verified with the `rbd` command on the central Ceph cluster) and then the instance will fail to boot on the dcn0 site.

neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py.message:
Hongbin, thanks a lot for the suggestion.
It seems to me that the flag-based solution might be better.
Using timestamp, we may not be able to guarantee that the RPC messages are processed strictly after the state sync has completed. BTW, using flag is also a simple way IMO.
Let's leave the solution open for now. Would you please kindly clarify the benefit of the proposed timestamp-based solution?

My concern on the flag-based approach is the risk of unintentional disabling of RPC. For example, right now, we rely on some condition to reset enable_rpc to True, but if the condition is unsatisfied (i.e. due to bug or unintentional changes), the rpc will be disabled permanently. The timestamp-based approach could mitigate this issue.

However, I don't have strong opinion on that. It is your call.

The concern makes sense to me in a way. Otherwise implementing a timeout (let's say twice the initial_delay) together w/ the flag-based approach might be a choice.
Let's have this open. I'm willing to adjust the implementation based on the feedbacks.
Are you sure all the subclass of DhcpAgent support report_state?
Not all subclass of DhcpAgent should support report_state. We should cover all the possible cases. The notes should be updated.
Should we check self.conf.report_interval as well?

Do we need to do this every time we execute run()?

This is not executed during the starting process. I mean, this change goes beyond the bug description (I'm not saying this is wrong).

Be aware this will require many RPC calls between the agent and the server.

Thanks for the comment.
It looks like that run is executed only when report_state is not supported or during the starting process [1][2][3]. Just correct me if I'm wrong.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L124
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L772
[3] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py#L778

How this will work in case when DHCP agent will just be restarted? If this initial_delay will be set to some quite high number (which should be the case for agent where we have a lot networks configured and initial sync may take long time) it will here wait this quite long time before sending heartbeat, right?
If so, it may cause that neutron-server will treat this agent as DOWN for some time. This may trigger removing of all networks from this DHCP agent.
If I'm right I don't think that this is good idea to add such delay here. Some time ago we moved heartbeat to separate workers to avoid such issues like agent flapping during the full sync and here You propose something which may do the same again.
Move the delay to run() to try not blocking heartbeat.
Done

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I'm not 100% happy with the updated listener operating status when this happens. It may be that the active amphora reports listener DOWN and the standby UP. We'd be elevating the listener operating status to DEGRADED when the active amphora's listener is not operational and thus not responding. It could also be the other way around, standby amp reports listener DOWN but active amp reports UP. Feedback is welcome.

octavia/controller/healthmanager/health_.message: Oops, it is a leftover from a draft patch.
Message not accurate any more based on above change.

This change is unrelated to this change but I thought about fixing it here nonetheless. 'lb_status' is the operating status which the LB should be updated to. What we want here is the LB operating status marked in the database.
This is incorrect as well. expected_listener_
I don't follow this either, sorry :/

This is incorrect behavior.
The LB may have 50 listeners and still be in a pending state adding one. If the LB is in PENDING, we should ignore the listener count, no matter what it is. We cannot assume this is the first listener on the LB.
We want to timestamp the DB no matter what if the LB is in a transitional state such as PENDING_* since we did get a packet from it.

I may be missing something here so apologies in advance. How do you see the amphora not being timestamped when in a PENDING state?

L161: update_amphora_health = True
L165: if in PENDING, jump to L229
L229: update_amphora_health == True
L253: timestamp is updated

Can you link me to where this is set as "DOWN" in the code?
As I read it, if the HAProxy process is not running, the stats socket will not be available and the agent would not send any message.
But that is a socket file, if the process behind it isn't running, there is nothing to read and it will fail.

When haproxy is killed -9'd and systemd does not respawn it, the stat socket file will still exist and the amphora-agent will read it. This case happens on multi-process haproxy amphorae (<= Rocky).

https://github.com/openstack/octavia/blob/b6181e272c852034a41df585a8d5047e5207b1a9/octavia/amphorae/backends/health_daemon/health_daemon.py#L120

nfv/nfv-vim/nfv_vim/strategy/_strategy.p.message: Are we going to allow an orchestrated firmware upgrade while a platform upgrade is in progress?

The question wasn't about orchestration - you are correct that we can only do one kind of orchestration at at time. The question was what the restriction is during an upgrade. For example, would there ever be a case where the customer starts a platform upgrade and then halfway through realizes they need to upgrade their firmware. The 900.005 alarm just says an upgrade is in progress (not an upgrade orchestration). We allow patch orchestration during an upgrade because it is possible that the upgrade might hit an issue that requires a patch to fix and our patching software works OK when hosts are running different releases. For FPGA upgrades, it is probably safe to say we can't do them at all during a platform upgrade, but just wanted to be sure that is what we want.
I'll do whatever design dictates. Feel free to specify. I can add the 900.005 back in.
I'm going to allow the 900.005 (sw upgrade in progress ; non-orchestrated). Same for 900.001 wrt patching.

I don't think you can. Certainly not an orchestrated one since  orchestration only supports one at a time. Recall the 'conflict detected' error discussion we had.

I asked about this in the dev channel.

I'm now going to remove all three 900.xxx alarms so that fw upgrade is gated while sw patch or sw upgrade is in progress.
Should be changed to the equivalent firmware upgrade alarm.
I'll add the fw upgrade alarms.

That is a good question. The original designer of the VIM was very strict about not having dependencies on platform services. So in the case of FM, the FM modules are only imported from the plugin directories.

I meant I will add them in a future update. Will add after the following question is answered.

Is there a reason why we don't use the definition 'FM_ALARM_ID_FW_UPGRADE_AUTO_APPLY_INPROGRESS' rather than the hard coded id '300.001' in the list.
Looks like you forgot to add the firmware upgrade alarms here. Without it, the orchestration will fail as soon as the alarm is raised.
Ok, so continue with current hard coding for IGNORE_ALARMS lists.
Will fix but the entire if/else clause needs to be tailored for accepting only unlocked-enabled hosts that support worker function.
Should probably update to AIO where you come across uses of CPE.

This needs to be moved.
